items.title: Updated hoodie-cli 0.3.2 to 0.4.0 -> hoodie start -> /_api/... 404 errors
items.body:
Hello,
NOTE: I'm writing this issue in hoodie-server because of the error type. Feel free to move it where appropriate.

Just updated hoodie-cli to 0.4.0.
I have a working application, started it with hoodie start and in the console (both terminal and Chrome console) begin to raise 404 errors like these.

```
GET http://127.0.0.1:6013/_api/user%2F_admin/_changes?include_docs=true&since=185 404 (Not Found) jquery-1.10.2.min.js:6
XHR finished loading: "http://127.0.0.1:6013/_api/user%2F_admin/_changes?include_docs=true&since=185". jquery-1.10.2.min.js:6
GET http://127.0.0.1:6013/_api/user%2F_admin/_changes?include_docs=true&since=185  jquery-1.10.2.min.js:6
GET http://127.0.0.1:6013/_api/  jquery-1.10.2.min.js:6
GET http://127.0.0.1:6013/_api/user%2F_admin/_changes?include_docs=true&since=185  jquery-1.10.2.min.js:6
GET http://127.0.0.1:6013/_api/  
```

Hoodie Version: 0.4.0 (node v0.10.22, npm 1.3.24, platform: linux)

Also, I tried to create a new application via hoodie new ... and when I start it from the directory, hoodie says: 
[hoodie] Could not start hoodie.

Do I have to upgrade something in my app's code?

UPDATE1: Rollback to 0.3.2 and having the same problems. Maybe is my fault or something with the DB after update (some key?).
What I find strange is that %2F html entity instead of a '/'.
I'll update this issue as soon as I find something else.

UPDATE2: Deleted everything, cloned back from the last saved version, and running with 0.3.2, it works flawlessly.
Tomorrow I will try to upgrade hoodie again.

items.title: hoodie.database(targetDb).add() should allow to pass _id and should not pass through _rev
items.body:
See https://github.com/espy/hoodie-plugin-tutorial/pull/9

Currently, when you pass a Hoodie object back to database().add() to be added as a new object in a different database, `_id` and `_rev` are passed through, which causes a ` { error: 'conflict', reason: 'Document update conflict.' }`.

database().add() should allow the forcing of an `_id` (reported as not working), but always filter out `_rev`.

items.title: rethink hoodie.config
items.body:
* the current `hoodie.config` API is synchronous, although it's using async hoodie.store API internally. That works today, but will break once hoodie.store is truly async
* `hoodie.config` is only used to persist the current hoodieId, username, last sequence nr (for sync) and a pending passwort reset request. All these are meant to remain local anyway, no sync is intended
* I thought `hoodie.config` would make a nice API that other developers could use, too. But to be honest, this is not based on a real use case and if that comes up, it might not be the right solution for it.

I would suggest we remove the API entirely, have a `config` module that is only accessible internally, and that implements it's own localStorage methods, so it works independently from hoodie.store, and always will be synchronous.

It would also prevent the weird problems that are happening when `_hoodieId` and `createdBy` properties from the `$hoodie/config` object diverge. 

Last but not least, the `$` prefix is now used for task object, which `$config` is not.

items.body:
- run 8 while(true); do casperjs test test/casper/index.coffee; done in parallel terminals, Hoodie eventually fails with:
 - Error: Callback was already called.
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:22:31
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/lib/changes_pool.js:39:20
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/lib/changes_pool.js:116:16
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:229:13
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:139:25
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/node_modules/async/lib/async.js:226:17
    at /Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/lib/changes_pool.js:144:16
    at IncomingMessage.<anonymous> (/Users/jan/Work/hoodie/apps/hoodie-minutes/node_modules/hoodie-server/node_modules/hoodie-plugins-manager/node_modules/couchr/couchr-node.js:175:32)
    at IncomingMessage.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:117:20)
    at _stream_readable.js:920:16

```
Object {state: function, always: function, then: function, promise: function, pipe: function}
PUT http://127.0.0.1:6004/_api/_users/org.couchdb.user%3A%24passwordReset%2Fundefined%2Fak3f22q 404 (Not Found) 
```

items.title: Make static hoodie.js easily available
items.body:
Hi, 
Why the default way to load hoodie.js is from remote server ( `/_api/_files/hoodie.js`)? This makes offline-first storage less useful, since i can't be offline and download hoodie.js.

Although one could manually download the script from api server to its assets folder it is very difficult to integrate hoodie.js in an independent build process this way.

So i suggest either to provide a static precompiled hoodie.js and plugins via bower.js or, to keep consistent with `hoodie-cli` way to install things: let's just add a new command to hoodie-cli eg. `hoodie compile-js [DEST]` so we can get the dynamic version of `hoodie.js` file right from the command line without running the server.

items.title: auto-initialize hoodie instance
items.body:
Adding & using Hoodie in your app requires you two to do two things today:

```html
<script scr="/path/to/hoodie.js"></script>
<script>hoodie = new Hoodie();</script>
```

While I think that there are still valid use cases for that, we could offer different versions of `hoodie.js` or do stuff like `data-hoodie-url` on the script tag, or `hoodie-no-initialize`. But the default would initializing hoodie by default, so we could do

```html
<script scr="/path/to/hoodie.js"></script>
<!-- hoodie is already available -->
```

This should cover by far most use cases and farther simplify the get started with Hoodie.

items.title: location of hoodie app on server
items.body:
The documentation states:

Creating a Hoodie app

$ hoodie new myappname
This created the folder 'myappname'. Go in there and start the default app:

$ cd myappname
$ hoodie start
Your browser should now automatically open and show you Hoodie's default app. If you don't want that, start the app with

$ hoodie start -n

Works like a charm. It is unclear however in what folder the app should be created. As I am running a server with no console, I used /var to create the app. When I create users from the client, they do NOT show up in the couchdb management console under x.x.x.x:5984. However, I can see the database in /var/myapp/data and the user database in /var/myapp/data/users.

I think the folder where the hoodie app is created should not be /var ?

items.title: Daemonize
items.body:
This is an invite to discuss the various ways Hoodie could run as a system daemon (at least on UNIX, Windows is out of scope for this one).

Today, `hoodie start` just keeps the tty open, making running Hoodie in the background an exercise left to the reader.

There are various schools of thought on this, but I think I come down on this: a program (hoodie) should just do what it does and delegate any daemonization to expert tools like init.d/runit etc.

A somewhat related question is how to handle automated installations of Hoodie that dont require manual intervention. Currently Hoodie asks for an admin pass on first start. There is an option to pass the `HOODIE_ADMIN_PASS` environment variable to avoid that, but it is unclear yet how this would work with init.d/runit.

Here are a few random notes:

`hoodie start`:
 - runs a hoodie instance
 - interactively asks for setup if none exists

init.d/runit etc scripts:
 - runs `hoodie start` as a system user, e.g.`hoodie` redirects stdout/err into /var/log/hoodie.log / .err

setup:
 - set up system user, e.g. `hoodie`
 - install hoodie app as hoodie (or adjust all perms accordingly)
 - make sure hoodie can write to /var/log & /var/run


open questions:
  - how to configure a hoodie installation (admin pass, port(s)) without manual intervention?
	  - how does HOODIE_ADMIN_PASS gets passed through init.d/runit etc?
  - how to handle multiple hoodie instances on a single machine?
	 - one answer is using docker, but that adds complexity to the setup
	 - another would be individual and customised init.d/runit etc scripts


Docker:
 See https://github.com/mozilla-appmaker/haas/blob/master/PLAN.md

items.title: Add additional data to to finished tasks for delivery back to the front end
items.body:
Imagine this use case.  Through a hoodie task a game app front end adds points to players score and the backend picks up the task to make an update and and evaluate this addition to determine if the points result in a a level up.  The backend can trigger a successful task completion like so:

    hoodie.task.success( db, doc, /*opt*/callback )

which currently updates the task doc with:

    '$processedAt': moment().format(),
    '_deleted': true

But other than generating another doc for the front end to listen for, there's seems to be no immediate way to close the loop with additional data to let the front end know that the points resulted in a level change.  Therefore, I propose:

    hoodie.task.success( db, doc, doneData, /*opt*/callback )

Where 'doneData' is any additional data to deliver back to the front end.

It appears I may be able to work around this by performing a manual update that mimic the success process (along with the add-on of my own cargo data), but adding something like this would be ideal.

Also, there dose not appear to be any documentation on the use of this method so I had to look for it in the source.  If I've missed something please let me know.

items.title: do not try to create databases for $passwordReset objects
items.body:
Right now it tries exactly that. To reproduce

1. Add this object to `/_users`

```json
{
   "_id": "org.couchdb.user:$passwordReset/funky@example.com/s7fdef2",
   "type": "user",
   "roles": [
   ],
   "password_scheme": "pbkdf2",
   "iterations": 10,
   "name": "$passwordReset/funky@example.com/s7fdef2",
   "createdAt": "2013-12-06T14:20:57.331Z",
   "updatedAt": "2013-12-06T14:20:57.190Z",
   "derived_key": "76df1ca4b5ab7cba7cba56675e325e9b2030bfcc",
   "salt": "2fc93de856fb68b317029efcc00c4fd6",
   "$error": {
       "error": "not_found",
       "message": "user funky@example.com could not be found"
   }
}
```

2. Start hoodie
3. You'll see the following error in the logs:

```
hoodie.database("user/undefined").grantReadAccess("$passwordReset", "funky@example.com"): Error: not_found
```

Besides that, I also see `hoodie.account.update: TypeError: Converting circular structure to JSON`, not sure if that is related or not.

items.title: CouchDB timeout on Mavericks
items.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to get a Hoodie app running on Mavericks, but getting errors.

I installed Homebrew into ~/.homebrew and then ran:

$ brew install couchdb

Got errors, which I fixed by installing latest Xcode CLT and re-installing Erlang

Then ran brew install couched again and it worked fine.

Next I ran:

$ npm install -g hoodie-cli
$ hoodie new testapp

That worked OK.

Finally, cd to test app and then ran:

$ hoodie start

Version: 0.3.2 (node v0.10.16, npm 1.3.15, platform: darwin)

Initializing...
CouchDB started: http://127.0.0.1:6003
Waiting for CouchDB [---*--] FAILED 

ERR! Error: Timed out waiting for CouchDB. These logs may help:

Checked the couchdb.err file:

heart_beat_kill_pid = 50683
heart_beat_timeout = 11
init terminating in do_boot ()
heart: Sat Dec  7 22:47:46 2013: Erlang is crashing .. (waiting for crash dump file)
/Users/nickroper/.homebrew/Cellar/couchdb/1.5.0/bin/couchdb: line 336: echo: write error: Broken pipe
heart: Sat Dec  7 22:47:47 2013: Executed "/Users/nickroper/.homebrew/Cellar/couchdb/1.5.0/bin/couchdb -k" -> 256. Terminating.

I can start CouchDB on its own OK though:

$ /Users/nickroper/.homebrew/bin/couchdb
Apache CouchDB 1.5.0 (LogLevel=info) is starting.
Apache CouchDB has started. Time to relax.
[info] [<0.31.0>] Apache CouchDB has started on http://127.0.0.1:5984/

Any ideas?

Thanks

items.title: custom session handling?
items.body:
I have several issues with Hoodie using cookies for sessions at the moment. One being, that I cannot end the session if the user is offline, but there are valid use cases for that, see https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie.js/issues/194

There are other reason, including security flaws, why I'd suggest to have that changed.

Instead of using cookies, I'd like to send a custom header with every request, something like `X-Hoodie-Session-Id`.

Does CouchDB support something like that? Or would that mean that we have to build our own session/auth handler?

items.title: Make hoodieStoreApi accessible to plugin developers
items.body:
Example: https://github.com/alanshaw/hoodie-plugin-memory-store

The [hoodieStoreApi](https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie.js/blob/master/src/hoodie/store.js#L41) is currently not accessible from outside. Developers that want to build upon it have no chance to do so. 

This is a follow up issue for #164

items.title: add optional timeout before local changes get pushed optional
items.body:
this is a follow up for #180.

### Latest Suggestion

```js
hoodie.store.add('doc', properties, {debounce: true})
```

### Meaning 

we do not push this update to remote, until you stop making changes for a moment (with the `debounce` option).

### Question 1

Any objections about adding such an option, and removing the default timeout?

### Question 2 

Is the meaning of `debounce` clear? Shall we call it differently?
related: http://underscorejs.org/#debounce

items.title: on signIn, $config/hoodie . createdBy gets set to wrong value
items.body:
The reason is, that hoodie.store prevents the user from overwriting the `createdAt` value, which makes sense. On `signout` event, a new `$config/hoodie` doc gets created and the `createdBy` gets set. Right after on `signin` event, the `createdBy` property cannot be overwritten anymore.

I think the entire way hoodie.config is implemented does not make much sense for several reasons and won't work if we move pouch. But I'll try to fix that specific issue only for now

items.title: add `wait_for_sync:true|false` option to store methods
items.body:
This would make the store call wait for sync.

The use case is for an app that needs data to be on the server before going on.

I dont have a need for this right now, but we could talk this through in case we get a user request for this.

items.title: replace hoodie.account.ownerHash with hoodie.id()
items.body:
see https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie.js/blob/master/src/hoodie/account.js#L1112

And I like the API, every user, no matter if signed up or not, has a **Hoodie ID**, that persists, and that can be used by apps or plugin devs for whatever.

- [ ] hoodiehq/hoodie-plugins-manager#12
- [ ] hoodiehq/hoodie-plugin-users#12

items.title: hoodie.task.start should accept {timeout: timeInMs} option
items.body:
After the timeout, in case the task is still pending, it should be canceled. On the server side, it should not be executed if the timeout passed.

All timestamps (`updatedAt`, `createdAt`) are in UTC today. There should be no timezone mambo

items.title: Password Reset: clean up when it failed
items.body: when a password reset failed, it should be removed with another PUT request from the client, after the error has been triggered.

items.title: Redirects through _api not passed properly
items.body:
When the Hoodie CouchDB config includes a reverse proxy setting such as:

    [httpd_global_handlers]
    _proxied = {couch_httpd_proxy, handle_proxy_req, <<"http://127.0.0.1:6052">>}

Which allow for a uri such as:

    http://127.0.0.1:6047/_api/_proxied

Any node express initiated redirect results in

    http://127.0.0.1:6048/_proxied/redirected

All direct calls to a route are handled properly.  The proxied server redirects like so:

    res.redirect('/redirected');

I'm not yet sure if this is a problem with the Hoodie reverse proxy or CouchDB's reverse proxy feature, but the problem appears to be somewhere in that chain.

FYI - I'm hoping to get this solved for smoother use of the Hoodie Social Authentication plugin I have under development.  See https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie-server/issues/169

items.title: add $startedProcessingAt: new Date()
items.body:
only send tasks to workers once we assigned a processing state to it. This avoids re-running of tasks that have been processed yet.

The value needs to be a timestamp in order to be able to clear inactive tasks after a timeout (Say 15 minutes) in case of a worker error.

items.title: add --keep-git option
items.body: sometimes it is useful to keep the .git folder when cloning a project. We should have an option for that :)

items.title: Add Port Availability Check
External CouchDB credentials cant include URL-chars
items.body: e.g. `x/m$$L3q*.H;bX` as a password in `HOODIE_ADMIN_PASS` will result in unauthenticated requests

items.title: less debug
items.body: `err` can be a really deep object totally plastering stdout, making other debugging hard.

items.title: Will hoodie support non-javascript front-ends?
items.body:
I am an iOS developer and looking at using a nobackend architecture for data exchange in my apps.  The client APIs look great and I'd like to consider creating an Objective-C version of the client to talk with the hood.ie backend.  

Is that something you see as 'in-line' with your intentions?  Or, do you see the API to the server as highly dynamic and not part of the stable release processes?

items.title: make hoodie.account.signOut() reject with better error when local changes cannot be pushed.
items.body:
Somewhat related to #194 

When user is offline & has local changes, then tries to sign out, he just gets an `Could not connect to Hoodie server at /.` error. But it should rather say that there are changes that have not yet been synched and that they could not be pushed.

items.title: make hoodie.account.signOut() resolve when offline & no local changes
items.body:
right now, when the user has an account, hoodie.account.signOut() tries to send a `DELETE` request. If it fails, it gets rejected. That makes sense, because we are using cookies for authentication and they only get removed when the `DELETE` request succeeds. If we would ignore the failing request, we would remove all local data and reset the user's hash & username, but towards CouchDB, the user would still have a valid session.

Not really sure how to solve this right now.

items.title: allow git-ssh URLs for `hoodie new`
items.body:
When trying to install a hoodie app that is not public into a production environment, itd be great to be able to tell `hoodie new` to use the git-ssh URL for the repo in order to be able to use deploy keys.

Maybe `hoodie new myapp owner/repo --use-ssh or something.

items.title: randonm id not being assigned to new db records
pass db as param even if file_exists error is raised on db add
items.body: subject says it all really

items.title: remove obsolete remote.on / remote.unbind definitions in account_remote.js
Remove dependencies
items.body:
Pocket currently depends on:

```
    "hoodie-app": "git://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie-app.git",
    "hoodie-worker-users": "git://github.com/hoodiehq/worker-users.git",
    "hoodie-worker-shares": "git://github.com/hoodiehq/worker-shares.git",
    "hoodie-worker-email-out": "git://github.com/hoodiehq/worker-email-out.git"
```

I assume this is because it was easier to develop in isolation, but Pocket should really not depend on these things, as it is itself a dependency for hoodie-server

items.title: hoodie.task.start does not reject ('error' event does not get triggered from store)
sendEmail error: make sure to set `message` property
items.body:
We recently normalized the error handling throughout the frontend code: https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie.js/pull/173

Whenever the backend sets an error that gets transported to the frontend, please make sure that the `message` property is set, optionally the `name` property to something like `HoodieAuthError`. You can optionally set farther properties for debugging etc. The `message` property supports placeholders in the form of `{{something}}` that get replaced with `$error.something` in the frontend.

In the case of nodelmailer, an error looks like this:

```js
$error = {
 data: "435 4.7.8 Error: authentication failed:",
 name: "AuthError",
 stage: "auth"
}
```

Ideally, it would look something like

```js
$error = {
 name: "HoodieEmailError",
 message: "Could not connect to email service. Please contact the ExampleApp support team at support@example.com",
 data: "435 4.7.8 Error: authentication failed:",
 stage: "auth"
}
```

items.title: selective fetch / event binding
items.body:
as of now, a collection fetches all records of it's model type, and listen to all events of it's model type.

But what if I want a collection that belongs to a parent record? In that case, it should only fetch records of its type, that belong to the respective parent record.

Think of a task list app, where each task is it's own record. How would I fetch only the records of task list A, but not B?

Does that make sense?

items.title: Wrong objects resolved from hoodie.store.removeAll()
Fix sauceLabs test for IE10 & IE11
items.body: follow up for #163 & #172

items.title: Reduce TTFH
items.body: Here is how we can discuss strategies to reduce the Time To First Hoodie.

items.title: Nodemailer support for direct sending
items.body:
Hi, just letting you know that Nodemailer (since v0.5.8) is able to send e-mails without any configuration - in this case an outgoing e-mail is delivered directly to the recipients MX server without using a relay service.

This is not the most reliable way for sending e-mails as e-mails sent from a dynamic IP address or from servers without good sending reputation might end up in the Spam folder more easily but it is a really simple way to bootstrap the application.

More information from [Nodemailer docs](https://github.com/andris9/Nodemailer#setting-up-direct-transport)

items.title: remove artificial timeout before local changes get pushed
items.body: The reason why this is in is that I wanted to let people save objects on any keyboard press, just like minutes.io is doing it. But truth is, this does not belong into hoodie core, cause by far not all apps are made this way.

items.title: adjust to new error formats
items.body:
Okay, that might sound confusing. What I mean is that we want to normalize the frontend error handling by following JavaScript's Error conventions of having a `name` and a `message` property. At the moment, we usually (but not always) followed CouchDB's way having an `error` and a `reason` property.

As we change it throughout the code in the frontend, it will be needed to be changed in the backend as well, at least where objects are updated with an `$error` property, like in 
https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie-plugin-users/blob/master/lib/password_reset.js#L53

That should now read

```js
$error: {
  name: 'HoodieNotFoundError',
  message: util.format('user %s could not be found', username),
  username: username
}
```

If you don't see any reasons, I'd let you know as soon as the frontend code code is ready, so we can publish all at once:
https://github.com/hoodiehq/hoodie.js/issues/173

Hope that makes all sense?

At the moment, we usually (but not always) followed CouchDB's way having an `error` and a `reason` property.

As we change it throughout the code in the frontend, it will be needed to be changed in the backend as well, at least where objects are updated with an `$error` property, like in

items.title: Access preference
items.body:
Best case from a user's perspective I think is to have this data available through the normal store api. That way if you had data the same kind of data (say todos) but some that was private and some that belong to the group, you could query for both with a single call to the store api.

If the doc has a property that specified the origin of the data (or it's realm), you could filter by that if it was important to you.
